newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore worried by rapid rise in elderly.
newsitem.headline: Singapore worried by rapid rise in elderly.

text.p: Singapore is worried by the rapidly increasing number of people over the age of 65 and the problems it will raise for the small island-state, Health Minister Teo Cheow Tong said on Sunday.
Yeo said in a speech before medical specialists that Singapore now has 210,000 people over the age of 65 in a population of 3.1 million people.
"By the year 2020, we will have about 530,000 elderly, or 13 percent of the population," he said.
"What is worrying is that, arising from the post-war baby boom, the number of elderly will increase even more rapidly after that."
Singapore's elderly population is projected to rise to 800,000 by 2030.
"They will then make up over 18 percent of the total population," Yeo said. "It has complex social, economic and health dimensions."

Experts have said the problem may be even more acute in Singapore because of its smaller population base compared with its neighbours like Indonesia, which has a population of nearly 200 million people.
One way Singapore is trying to cope is to raise the retirement age, Yeo said. Beginning in January 1999, the retirement age will be increased to 62 years from 60.
Yeo said "the longer term plan of eventually raising it to 67 years," the Health Minister said. "Employment gives the elderly person a sense of worth, dignity and financial independence."
Yeo did not elaborate on his remarks but said Singapore needed to identify the most efficient and effective way to meet the health care needs of the elderly.
Putting the elderly in institutions is not a solution because "it is difficult to replicate the warm emotional environment and support of their own family settings," he said.
The number of nursing home beds is expected to rise to around 7,000 by the year 2000 from the current 4,400.
